results.title: Jump for glory
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Marcel Hellman and Criterion Film Productions
results.brief_description: In this romantic crime drama, a cat burglar gets emotionally involved with one of his victims. Unfortunately, the woman he woos is engaged to the thief’s treacherous ex-partner. The louse has reformed and to all appearances is an honest, successful businessman. But appearances are deceiving. The two men end up battling it out. Later the businessman is found dead. Unfortunately, during the trial, the blame is placed upon the girl. The thief tries to take the rap for her. In the end, however, it is revealed that the businessman actually killed himself after a stock market crash.

results.title: In the company of men
results.creator_credit: Neil LaBute, Stephen Pevner, Mark Archer, Fair and Square Productions and Atlantis Entertainment
results.brief_description: This lacerating black comedy is an acerbic commentary on modern day masculinity. Two businessmen, sent by their company to oversee new company offices in another city, undertake a scheme to enact revenge on contemporary women. They plan to find a woman, wine and dine her, seduce her and then cruelly dump her. From this initial premise Neil Labute crafts an exceptionally taut and challenging work which explores the misogyny, racism and selfishness that underlies the competitive ethos of the new yuppie capitalist culture. Aaron Eckhart gives an outstanding performance as Chad, who imbues his vile character with a disturbing attractiveness. He is ably supported by Matt Malloy as his best friend who allows his personal morality and ethics to be subsumed by his desire to be “one of the boys”; and by Stacy Edwards as the “victim” who the men choose to abuse. Filmed in long takes which allow the actors to take centre stage, featuring excellent production design and music, “In the Company of Men” packs a mighty emotional punch. The end suggests that the culture of misogyny engendered by modern corporatism is as destructive on men as it is on women.

results.title: Raining stones
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Film Four International and Parallax Pictures
results.brief_description: Set on a council estate in Middleton on the outskirts of Manchester, “Raining Stones” is an uncompromising look at England’s poorest citizens in a country where unemployment has created an alienated underclass and bred petty crime, vandalism, drug abuse and poverty. Already barely making ends meet, Bob supports his family by doing odd jobs. When his only asset, his van, is stolen, the family’s prospects become even grimmer. Now unemployed he is still determined to find the money to buy a new communion dress for his daughter’s first communion - even if it means turning to crime. Without ever mentioning politics, Loach makes a powerful and effective political statement about the way economic policies destroy social coherence. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize, Cannes Film Festival, 1993)

results.title: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould
results.creator_credit: Francois Girard, Niv Fichman and Rhombus Media
results.brief_description: Thirty two short films about Glenn Gould is an inventive and playful film that seeks to portray the genius, complex and eccentric personality of legendary pianist, Glenn Gould. The film borrows its structure from JS Bach’s Goldberg Variations (and name from Beethoven’s “32 variations in C Minor”), and juxtaposes 32 short vignettes to portray the broadly influenced Gould. The film uses a combination of interview, dramatisation and animation, punctuated with the music of Gould’s live performances (mostly Bach, Beethoven and Shoenberg) to humorously fill the portrait of Gould. Included is an excerpt from Norman McLaren’s experimental animation ‘Spheres’ and Gould’s live radio broadcast of 28th December 1967, ‘The Idea of North’. Peppered throughout are Gould’s philosophical ruminations such as, “for every hour you spend with people you need x more hours on your own”.

results.title: The Bride of Frankenstein
results.creator_credit: James Whale, Carl Laemmle and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Using the device of a prologue in which Mary Shelley takes up her story, the monster and Frankenstein were resurrected at Universal’s behest. Although the threads of continuity in the plot are explicit, in tone this is not really a sequel but a macabre comedy, an excursion into the fantastic which hovers between expressionism and surrealism. Karloff’s monster is the only sympathetic character. The mad scientist, Dr. Pretorius, seems to take over the evil presumptions of Frankenstein. As originally conceived, the heart of Frankenstein’s bride, Elizabeth, was to have been implanted in the she-monster. This makes more sense of the title and the she-monster’s behaviour. Suggested by the original story written in 1816 by Mary Wollstonecroft Shelley. Also includes a comprehensive documentary detailing various aspects of the production, including music, make-up, and behind-the-scenes information.

results.title: Appleseed
results.creator_credit: Kazuyoshi Katayama, Masaki Sawanobori, Atsushi Sugita, Taro Maki and Manga Entertainment
results.brief_description: A dark, cyberpunk anime set far in the future. World War Three has plunged society into a state of anarchy. To try and resolve the problems created by war, the remaining governments band together to create Olympus, an experimental city designed as a sanctuary for the surviving humanity. However, this new paradise is also home to a new species, the Bio-Droid, a cyborg slave specifically created to administer the city. Some of the citizens are extremely unhappy with this brave new world, and long for liberty - at any price. After terrorists try to destroy the city, special SWAT teams are called in to try and neutralise the situation. Terrorist AJ Sebastian manages to escape from police custody by murdering an officer. Horrified by what has occurred, police offider Dunan Nats and her cyborg partner, Buliaros Hekatonecles, transfer to investigations in order to hunt down and arrest him, before he has the chance to destroy Olympus. A fast-paced anime, filled with heavy weaponry, fascinating mecha, and enough references to characters and places in Greek mythology for the viewer to get a clear sense of the underlying concerns of this animation. This film is based on an original story by Masamune Shirow, who published the first book in the Appleseed series “The Promethean Challenge”, in 1985. In 1986, the Appleseed books won him the Galaxy Award for the best sci-fi manga. In general, Shirow’s inspiration derives from reading extensively, particularly in the areas of science, medicine, the supernatural, military strategy, biology, nanotechnology, and mythology, which is particularly apparent in Appleseed.

results.title: Sin the movie (D)
results.creator_credit: Yasunori Urata, Andrew Orjuela and ADV Films
results.brief_description: Based on a popular video game, Sin the Movie is a compelling, action-packed tale set in Earth’s dystopic future. The city of Freeport has been rocked by a number of unexplained abductions involving a mutant humanoid. Colonel John Blade, leader of the elite strike force, Hardcorps, makes it his business to solve the mystery after one of his team is murdered by the monster. His efforts lead him to Sintek Industries, a multibillion dollar corporation headed by Elexis Sinclaire, brilliant biochemist and vicious vixen. When an adopted child, Elyse, is kidnapped, John and JC, the sister of his dead team-member, join forces to destroy the mutant, and stop Elexis from unleashing a genetically-engineered apocalypse upon the city. The director of this animation, Yasunori Urata, has been linked with a number of other important anime works, and is renowned for his stories, which combine human drama with spectacular action.

results.title: Masque of the red death
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman, George Willoughby and Alta Vista Productions
results.brief_description: On a mist-shrouded hill, an old woman crosses paths with a masked stranger in red, who gives her a rose and promises that the villages’ day of deliverance from the sadistic Prince Prospero is at hand. The Satan-worshipping Prospero (Vincent Price) blackmails the virtuous Francesca (Jane Asher) into coming to his castle in order to to save the lives of her fiancee and his father. Francesca recoils from the debauched decadence of the devil-worshipping nobles seeking sanctuary from the red death, and encounters Lady Juliana, who aspires to be the bride of Satan. In classical horror film fashion, Francesca spends much of her time prowling the baroque corridors of Prospero’s abode at midnight, stumbling upon Satanic rituals and being frightened by eerie noises. Eager to remove her rival from the castle, Juliana assists Francesca to escape, but unfortunately, Prospero is one step ahead of them, and detains Francesca again. Ashamed of leaving her in Prospero’s tainted hands, Gino attempts a rescue effort, but is stopped by the mysterious stranger in red, who offers to help as long as Gino does not attempt to enter the castle. The stranger confronts Prospero - who mistakes him for Satan - and all hell breaks loose as his identity is exposed. An atmospheric piece of gothic horror from the king of low-budget cult cinema, Roger Corman, loosely adapted from a story by Edgar Allen Poe.

results.title: The Black cat
results.creator_credit: Edgar G. Ulmer, Carl Laemmle Jnr and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Honeymooners Peter and Joan Allison are travelling through Eastern Europe on the Orient Express when a double-booking finds them sharing their compartment with the gracious but brooding Dr. Vitus Werdergast (Bela Lugosi). After Joan is injured when their bus crashes on a deserted road, Werdergast and the Allisons take shelter in the sepulchral home of Hjalmar Poelzig (Boris Karloff), one of Austria’s greatest architects. Werdergast has just finished tending to Joan’s injuries when the cadaverous Poelzig, swathed in severe black robes, makes an appearance. Werdergast reveals he has waited fifteen years for the chance to both find his wife Karen, and their daughter, and to kill Poelzig, whom he is convinced knows something about their disappearance. The sadistic Poelzig - who is also a High Priest heading a cult of devil-worshippers - decides to hold them all captive, and torments Werdergast by revealing the fate of his family. After Joan starts exhibiting some strange behaviour, it is up to Werdergast to try and save her from becoming the bride of Lucifer while seeking the opportunity to exact revenge on the man who destroyed his life. An atmospheric and chilling classic, featuring fine performances from Lugosi and Karloff in their respective roles. The concept of this film was very loosely suggested by the story “The Black Cat” by Edgar Allen Poe.

Werdergast reveals he has waited fifteen years for the chance to both find his wife Karen, and their daughter, and to kill Poelzig, whom he is convinced knows something about their disappearance. The sadistic Poelzig - who is also a High Priest heading a cult of devil-worshippers - decides to hold them all captive, and torments Werdergast by revealing the fate of his family. After Joan starts exhibiting some strange behaviour, it is up to Werdergast to try and save her from becoming the bride of Lucifer while seeking the opportunity to exact revenge on the man who destroyed his life. An atmospheric and chilling classic, featuring fine performances from Lugosi and Karloff in their respective roles. The concept of this film was very loosely suggested by the story “The Black Cat” by Edgar Allen Poe.

results.title: The Last temptation of Christ [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cineplex Odeon and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: A controversial and challenging film of Jesus Christ’s life. Based on the novel by Nikos Kazantzakis, this Christ is an anguished, vain, sensual man battling the forces of both good and evil. The film traces the conflicts that lead to his final disavowal of the flesh in favour of the life of the son of God. Scorsese had for years tried to film the Kazantzakis’ novel and on its release it was met with great debate and fury. The film, however, is deeply spiritual. With Willem Dafoe as Jesus, Barbara Hershey as Mary Magdalene, Harvey Keitel as Judas, and an impressive cameo by David Bowie as Pontius Pilate. Music by Peter Gabriel.
